page.title: 06FORTHAMPTON COURT
page.content: The road approaching Forthampton Court is still lined by sycamore trees which were first planted in 1898 and today the gamekeeper lives in the lodge on the drive. The exact origin of the manor is unknown, but it was probably built about 1240 by Abbot Robert de Fortington. Since then many parts have been added and altered. The outside of the manor shows the irregular shapes preferred by the famous architect Philip Webb, who added the square tower on the South-West front. The house came into the Yorke family via marriage in 1762. Today the house retains much of the fabric of a large Medieval manor house with its oak staircase and Great Hall. The Yorke's live in the house and it is not open to the public.
